Peter C's message brings up another issue that might be useful to
Peter B: =
 For ambulation, it might be more effective to use leaky
integrator neurons=
 than the usual feedforward neurons that are used in
most ANN models.  The =
leaky integrators are better for precise timing.
 However, they may not be =
necessary if joint angles are being provided
as input.  But when joint angl=
es are not provided, I do not think I
have ever seen a regular recurrent AN=
N (i.e. non-leaky or not some
other special type of neuron) be able to make=
 something walk.  In
fact, the "flailing" motions are often reduced signifi=
cantly by leaky
integrator neurons.  Tyler Streeter saw this when he worked=
 on his
biped with NEAT, which actually stopped flailing after switching to=

leaky integrators.  However, in his project the network had no inputs
and =
worked entirely through internal pattern generation.

ken

ogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi Peter,=

> 
> I cannot add more to what Ken said, this is an entirely new field and=

project as well (it is located in the files section in this group). 
> It i=
s written in C++ and utilizes HyperNEAT for constructing the 
> phenotypes.=
 It also uses leaky integrators for the phenotype neuron 
> model. The outp=
uts there are not joint torques, but the desired angle 
> of the joint.
> I=
t might be helpful to you, since we are both trying to achieve the 
> same =
thing actually :)
> By the way I want to ask you if we could join forces to=
 collaborate 
> on such a project because it is a very interesting thing an=
d I have 
> some experience with it. You can contact me in Skype (spookey85=
) if 
> you agree. 
> 
> Peter Chervenski
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "peterberrington" <peterberrington@> 
> wrote:
> >

ck response Ken!

onder the

 this 
> domain.

recently, its 
> really
> > messy and I'm sure my code can use a LOT of imp=
rovement (I was kind 
> of
> > learning as I went along). I only wrote the =
toribash-esque 
> experiment
> > and a few changes and features added to py=
thon-neat. The actual
> > python-neat backend is written by Cesar Gomez and=
 is really 
> terrific,
> > as python has a certain elegance about it that =
makes it seem easier 
> to
> > grasp. 
> > 
> > In order to get it to work =
you need to download the linux version of
> > Command Line Breve:
> > http:=
//www.spiderland.org/download.php
> > Then unzip this in the breve_2.7.2/ d=
irectory:
> > http://peter.berrington.googlepages.com/tori.7z
> > 
> > To e=
volve, open a shell and navigate to the breve directory, then 
> call
> > t=
he ToriExp with python, like this:
> > python tori/toriExp.py
> > To view t=
he last best individual, instead type this:
> > ./bin/breve tori/viewlastbe=
st.py
> > 
> > Theres a HUGE amount of parameters for which I have no idea =
what the
> > good values are. The creator of Toribash is giving me a descri=
ption 
> of
> > how his game works but is not at all forthcoming with the s=
pecific
> > implementation details; I suppose he is reluctant to give away =
code
> > for something he makes money on, but it's frustrating as his game =
is
> > actually very well balanced, allowing some very nimble and natural
>=
 > looking acrobatics. Trial and error is probably the only solution at
> >=
 this stage.
> > 
> > I encourage people to fool around with this; I'm a co=
mplete beginner
> > to programming this kind of stuff and I've got a lot of=
 really

hink
> > would make sense.

> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenn=
eth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi Peter, that's a good questio=
n and of course learning to 
> control a 
> > > virtual creature with novel=
ty search is a complicated issue (and 
> an 
> > > appealing idea as well).=
 
> > > 
> > > First, you have to deal with all the representational and 
>=
 physical 
> > > issues outside of novelty search, like how many inputs, ho=
w many 
> > > outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically flawed=
 in 
> > > some way (which is possible).  As you are experiencing, the 
> >=
 > inputs/outputs issue can be prohibitive even with feature 
> > > selecti=
on.  It is also possible that HyperNEAT could be useful 
> > > because it d=
oes not care about the # inputs or outputs (and can 
> > > potentially expl=
oit geometric regularities), but configuring the 
> > > substrate then beco=
mes the challenge.
> > > 
> > > Assuming all of that stuff is set up well w=
ith whatever system, 
> then 
> > > novelty search is a potentially winning=
 approach.  Yet as you 
> point 
> > > out there are some big questions the=
re as well.  In fact, we are 
> > > currently trying to provide the best an=
swers to these questions 
> in 
> > > ongoing research, but some general pr=
inciples might help for now: 
> > > 
> > > First, the archive in novelty se=
arch does not not need to contain 
> > > every point ever visited.  Therefo=
re, it tends to grow much 
> slower 
> > > than the #of evaluations.  Howev=
er, if it is indeed getting too 
> big  
> > > then it is not unreasonable =
to collapse some of the archive 
> points, 
> > > although there is no stan=
dard method yet for how that should be 
> > > done.  But we have reason to =
believe there will be effective and 
> > > simple ways to do that.
> > > 
>=
 > > Second, the issue of one individual looking different just 
> because =

> > > of a phase difference in effectivley the same behavior is 
> > > com=
plicated.  For certain phase disaparities, the two individuals 
> > > won't=
 look all that different, but it is true that at some 
> > > disparity, the=
y may look very different.  Yet it is not clear 
> > > whether that fact is=
 actually problematic to the novelty search 
> or 
> > > not, because it wo=
uld simply reward both types of behavior.  It 
> is 
> > > possible that th=
e phase difference is a result of some useful 
> > > genotypic change, whic=
h could make it a stepping stone to 
> something 
> > > better.  Or, it is =
possible that it is superfluous information 
> and 
> > > simply takes some=
 extra time exploring the area around the phase-
> > > shifted individual. =
 So it is hard to say a priori whether it is 
> a 
> > > major concern.  We=
 will have better answers to such questions as 
> the 
> > > technique is f=
urther explored.
> > > 
> > > However, I agree that it would be nice to be =
able to say the two 
> > > phase-shifted individuals are largely the same i=
f that is indeed 
> > > what you want to say.  And for that, you would need=
 a pattern-
> > > matching metric to compute behavioral distance, i.e. some=
thing 
> more 
> > > sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance.  There =
are 
> certainly 
> > > such metrics available.  However, it's important to=
 recognize 
> that 
> > > it is not evident at this point that ignoring the=
 phase shift is 
> > > actually better than taking it into consideration, b=
ecause taking 
> it 
> > > into consideration just means adding more inform=
ation to the 
> novelty 
> > > landscape.
> > > 
> > > So overall I think n=
ovelty search is a very promising direction 
> to 
> > > go for such proble=
ms, but it is still in the realm of research 
> (i.e. 
> > > there is no ex=
isting precedent), so it will involve considerable 
> > > trial and error t=
o get it right until all these issues are 
> fleshed 
> > > out more clearl=
y.  Ultimately, though, if our hypothesis about 
> > > novelty vs. fitness =
is correct, novelty search may turn out to be 
> > > the *only* way to get =
certain highly complex types of behavior to 
> > > evolve in some domains, =
which is a sobering thought.  But if it 
> is 
> > > true, then there is no=
t much to do other than try it.
> > > 
> > > ken
> > >

ahoogroups.com, "peterberrington" <peterberrington@>

=

cinating

ter the one in Toribash, a free game

amics engine for physics, like breve.

on in his latest paper, trying to make a

esults in it falling over perpetually. You can

IP videos at my youtube page here:

aircrow

Toribash game

yer- I think 
> this 
> > > goal
> > > > is attainable despite being diffic=
ult.

e
> > > > integrated distance from a goal, it encourages the behaviour of 
=
> the
> > > > "Tori" balancing in a stable configuration forever, rather th=
an
> > > > walking, which is what I'm trying to encourage. As there is 20 
=

> > > > in this rig, I am providing joint position and velocit=
y 
> information
> > > > for each joint, as well as a bias, a sine-wave, th=
e x, y, and z
> > > > components linear velocity in the reference frame of =
the Tori's 
> > > head,
> > > > and finally 3 variables which correspond to=
 the vertical, 
> > > horizontal
> > > > and forward orientation of the tor=
i's head with respect to world
> > > > coordinates.  
> > > > The current e=
xperimental configuration I am started out as 
> a "pure"
> > > > ragdoll c=
ontrol where neural net outputs correspond directly 
> joint
> > > > veloci=
ty; a tanh activation function is used to allow positive 
> and
> > > > neg=
ative joint movement.
> > > > I then remodeled the experiment to perform as=
 in the Toribash 
> game;
> > > > the net will receive inputs (and effect j=
oint movements) only 
> > > every 10
> > > > time steps. More importantly, =
I increased the amount of outputs 
> > > from
> > > > 20 (1 per joint) to 4=
0, in order to accomodate the 4 possible 
> joint
> > > > actions which can=
 occur on a turn: holding, relaxing, 
> extending, 
> > > and
> > > > flexi=
ng. 
> > > > 
> > > > Starting with a fully connected net, that gives a sta=
ggeringly 
> huge
> > > > search space with over 1000 connections. Due to t=
he 
> implementation,
> > > > its prohibitively slow to evolve large nets a=
s the starting net 
> can
> > > > take up over 600mb of ram on the heap. Re=
alizing this was a bit
> > > > ridiculous, I implemented feature selection =
and phased pruning.
> > > > However, even with this, deception seems to pre=
vent any useful
> > > > behaviour; the Tori will always get stuck in ruts.
=
> > > > 
> > > > 
> > > > I am using a python implementation of neat develo=
ped by Cesar 
> Gomez
> > > > under the GPL, which is available at 
> http:=
//code.google.com/p/neat-
> > > python/

n is a WIP and I've already done a lot of 
> tests

orate the linear genome encoding taken from the

> > > > method.=
 I've also been trying to incorporate CMA-ES in order to

eights but I haven't had much success meshing this 
> with 
> > > the
> > >=
 > rest of the code yet.

 post my source files for

> > > who

 with virtual creature neuroevolution.

> > > > F=
INALLY, my question. The behaviour of a Tori is currently 
> > > represente=
d
> > > > as a list of 20 base 4 variables multiplied by the amount of 
> t=
ime
> > > > steps the Tori is evaluated for. The novelty search method 
> p=
roposed
> > > > for the 2d maze navigation is fairly simple; if theres a ne=
w 
> ending
> > > > point then 
> > > > we add that point to a list of disc=
overed behaviours. This 
> works

> > > > (I imagine) because a =
point isn't a lot of information to hold.

now is how I can compare the behaviour of 2

> > > > controllers =
for novelty; is there any compact encoding that

e it often takes 25 000 seperate evaluations to get

> > > > useful b=
ehaviour out of this right now, theres going to have to

way to store 20k seperate behaviours in some way that is

her

st

 were 100% unique, yet

otice the similarity in how they act.
